hi! how do i remove older kernel version: should i just type rm *version* ?
i actualy deleted them the other day because i had no space in the boot drive...
how many linux kernels do you see?

go to System > Administration > Synaptic package manager. Click on "Status" on the lower left corner. See inside "Installed (local or obsolete)" - Select a package you what you want to remove, right-click on it and press "Mark for Complete Removal".  Also in Status, check out "Not Installed (residual config)"
wich packages should i change then?

the "Not installed (residual config)" are all safe to mark for complete removal. it's packages you removed and have leftover configuration files (removes stuff from root system files/folders, NOT your home directory configuration files)
in "Installed (local or obsolete)" lists packages that YOU installed (with a .deb file) or packages that are NOT supported anymore. All linux-image* packages in there are safe to remove.
how do i get my "2.6.24-23" kernel back? i only have "2.6.24-22" now...
which ubuntu release are you using?
go to Applications > Accessories > Terminal and paste the output of this command: uname -a
here it is: "Linux multivac 2.6.24-22-generic #1 SMP Mon Nov 24 18:32:42 UTC 2008 i686 GNU/Linux"
ok now the output of this command: lsb_release -r
can you paste at www.pastebin.com (and give me the link) the output of: apt-cache policy linux-generic linux-image-2.6.24-23-generic
it is like i told you... http://pastebin.com/m50cb9c7f i just deleted the wrong files on my /boot ...
execute this (all in one line): sudo apt-get update; sudo apt-get install --reinstall linux-generic linux-image-2.6.24-23-generic; sudo dpkg-reconfigure linux-image-2.6.24-23-generic
if asked something, press "Y" and hit enter :)
i had already tried the "reinstall linux-generic" part... :)
seems to have worked.
thx
ok, glad to hear it :)
